stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on programming a physics-based paper airplane mechanic for Course 14, which involved extensive trial-and-error to achieve a specific flight path. He also implemented a star-giving Toad NPC, created a placeholder animation for a rubber band slingshot, and discussed his off-stream progress on fixing N64 hardware bugs for the upcoming game demo.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is implementing a paper airplane mechanic using a physics-based simulation rather than a pre-scripted path, preferring the authenticity even if it requires extensive trial-and-error with variables.
development_findings.quote: Of course, I can just put it on a spline, but then I just have to add a spline and doing these computations, I prefer that. That's why there's some kind of physical basis for it.

development_findings.summary: The demo for the game is considered 'all done,' with significant off-stream work completed to fix N64 hardware-specific bugs related to anti-aliasing, z-ordering, and textures. A full playthrough on console is still needed for final verification.
The game is being developed with a stretched 16:9 aspect ratio, which causes visual artifacts like stretched text, though it supports a native 16:9 mode on emulators.
development_findings.quote: The game runs in like stretched 16 to 9, which causes that to happen. If you ran the game in native 16 to 9, which on emulator you can do... this would not be an issue.

development_findings.summary: The game's performance is currently limited by the N64's Reality Signal Processor (RSP), which is being addressed by using modern, more efficient microcodes like F3DEX3.
development_findings.quote: My game now is RSP bottlenecked.

development_findings.summary: Kaze diagnosed and fixed a bug where an animation was importing incorrectly, tracing it to an optimization feature in the Fast64 tool that was unintentionally removing the first keyframe.
development_findings.quote: No, the first animation frame wasn't exporting because there's a smart animation range feature That cuts out all the frames until the first one... because I didn't have a keyframe before the first frame. I just cut the first frame

development_findings.summary: Kaze briefly used ChatGPT to generate dialogue for a mechanical-sounding Toad NPC but ultimately dismissed the result as 'shit'.
development_findings.quote: Visitor detected, dispensing star. Take it.

development_findings.summary: The level being worked on, Course 14, has a working title of 'Handmade Heights' and features multiple biomes including a desert with pyramids, styrofoam mountains, a castle, and grasslands.
Kaze finished programming paper targets off-stream, which can be broken by Mario, and added a new cannon to the level.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the quality bar for 3D platformers is very low, and that a game can be successful simply by not having frustrating elements, even if it isn't exceptional.
context_findings.quote: I always bring up Battle for Bikini Bottom. That game is so nothing. There's nothing good in the game. But there's also nothing bad in the game... The lack of bad stuff with just the presence of a small bit of good stuff already makes it a fan favorite for many.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a love-hate relationship with streaming, stating that while he enjoys it, the repetitive or unhelpful questions from the live chat can be more frustrating than the development work itself.
context_findings.quote: You know, I thought what made you insane when you rommake is like the rommaking itself. But no, it's Twitch chat like watching you rommake.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is skeptical about the upcoming Analogue 3D console and believes the company's lack of engagement with him for a review suggests the product may be flawed.
context_findings.quote: If they're not sending me a review copy or an early copy to review it, surely there's a reason for that. And surely that means it's garbage, right?

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans to develop his own original 3D platformer using Unreal Engine 5 after completing Return to Yoshi's Island.
context_findings.quote: I have to make my own game. I keep mixing up obj's default and obj's level. We're running at a higher resolution, I don't see it. No, anti-aliasing is usually a per-polygon effect, it's nothing to do with textures. What you're describing is one way to kind of make anti-aliasing work in Photoshop, but it's nothing to do with what I did here. You're thinking of mipmap levels. Mipmap levels is like a lower resolution version of the texture, that you can swap it with a further way, that kind of reduces the flickering. No, it will be a modded game in Unreal Engine 5. Most likely.

context_findings.summary: He plans to continue using his personal YouTube channel for marketing the current fan project but would create a dedicated account for a future commercial game.
context_findings.quote: I feel like if we do a real game, that's where we should make a separate social media account and then I can still post garbage on my main accounts and advertise the social media account at the same time.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a strong work ethic and is critical of those who use common obligations like school as a reason for not having enough time for their passion projects.
context_findings.quote: I've always been a hater for people that are like, oh, I can't work on my R64 because I have school. Bitch, school is like six hours a day. You still are awake for 10 hours a day beyond that. You have all the time you want and you're just being a pussy.

biobak.summary: Biobak made a brief appearance in the stream chat, and Kaze's greeting suggests a shared, humorous understanding of the frustrations of live development.
biobak.quote: Hello, Biobak. Welcome to programming this and getting annoyed by chat. What else is new?

zeina.summary: Kaze confirms Zeina's role as the project's animator, noting that his own animation work (like the rubber band) is just a placeholder for her to finalize.
zeina.quote: it's technically fine because I'm not the animator for this game anyway. Really, I just need a decent base so that we can make this work.

zeina.summary: Zeina was present off-camera during the stream, and Kaze shared his progress on the paper plane mechanic with her in a casual interaction.
zeina.quote: Hello Zeina, what are you doing? We just did the paper airplane. Look at it.

key_stories.title: Taming the Chaotic Paper Plane
key_stories.summary: Kaze dedicated most of the stream to programming the physics for a paper airplane. He deliberately chose a complex, physics-based approach for authenticity, leading to a frustrating but revealing trial-and-error process of taming a 'volatile, chaotic system' to achieve the exact flight path he envisioned.
key_stories.challenge: To create a dynamic and physically authentic flight path for a paper airplane that would carry Mario to a specific landing spot on a pyramid, without resorting to a simple, pre-scripted animation.
key_stories.process: Kaze spent the majority of the stream in a loop of adjusting code variables (velocity, pitch, gravity, friction, and other 'fudge factors'), compiling, and observing the result. The plane's behavior swung wildly from doing backflips to being too stable to flying straight into the ground. He methodically isolated variables and expressed frustration with both the complexity and the chat's suggestions before finally honing in on a working set of values.
key_stories.outcome: After a long process of tweaking numerous physics variables, Kaze successfully created a flight path that swooped up and down in a way he found satisfying. He then used a simple timer to stop the plane at the precise moment to ensure it landed correctly.
key_stories.key_quote: I mean, obviously it's an approximation of real physics. This is just such a volatile, chaotic system.

key_stories.title: The Missing First Frame
key_stories.summary: While implementing a simple rubber band animation, Kaze ran into a technical snag where the animation started incorrectly. The problem was a subtle feature in his export tool that was removing the first frame. His ability to diagnose and solve this tool-specific issue highlights the deep technical knowledge required for this type of development.
key_stories.challenge: An animation for a rubber band, created in Blender, was not playing correctly in-game. It appeared to start from the wrong position, breaking the illusion of it launching the paper plane.
key_stories.process: After importing his placeholder animation, Kaze noticed it was behaving incorrectly. He initially suspected an error in his implementation or the animation data. He investigated the execution order of his code and considered it might be a bug in Fast64. He eventually realized the tool's 'smart animation range' optimization was the culprit.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze correctly diagnosed that the issue was not the animation itself, but a feature in his tool, Fast64. By adding a keyframe on frame 0, he forced the tool to export the intended first frame, fixing the animation.
key_stories.key_quote: No, the first animation frame wasn't exporting because there's a smart animation range feature That cuts out all the frames until the first one.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions he is creating placeholder animations and that Zeina is the project's main animator. He also has a brief, friendly interaction with Biobak in chat.
questions: Can you walk us through the creative hand-off process between you and the other team members? For example, when you finish a placeholder animation for Zeina, what does that look like?
How does the feedback loop work with Biobak for graphics or Badub for music? Do you provide a detailed brief, or is it more of a collaborative jam session?
How much does the live feedback from team members dropping into your stream influence the immediate direction of your work?

open_questions.topic: Design Philosophy: Simulated vs. Scripted Events
open_questions.context: Kaze spent hours programming a complex, physics-based flight path for a paper airplane that the player cannot control, stating he prefers it because it has a 'physical basis' rather than being a simple scripted event.
questions: Why is it so important for you to have underlying physical complexity in non-interactive elements like the paper plane?
How do you decide when it's worth investing significant time into a complex backend system versus creating something the player can directly interact with?
Does this philosophy of creating a 'physical basis' for objects appear in other parts of the game? Can you give another example?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated the public demo is 'all done' and that he's invested significant time in fixing bugs to ensure it runs well on original N64 hardware.
questions: You've put a lot of effort into N64 hardware compatibility. Why is perfect performance on original consoles, not just emulators, a priority for you?
What are your main goals for releasing this demo? What specific feedback are you hoping to receive from the community?
How will the reception and feedback from this demo shape the final months of development on the full project?

open_questions.context: Kaze confirmed he plans to create his own original 3D platformer in Unreal Engine 5 after this project is finished. He has strong opinions on the genre, believing the quality bar is currently 'incredibly low'.
questions: You said a game can succeed by just being 'not bad'. For your own original game, what are the key principles you'll follow to create something that is genuinely 'good'?
How has the process of deconstructing and fundamentally altering Super Mario 64 prepared you for building a new 3D platformer from the ground up?
What creative possibilities do you feel a modern engine like Unreal 5 opens up for you that you've felt constrained by with the N64?
